Introduction

Rhinitis is a common condition that represents a spectrum of inflammatory disorders affecting the nasal mucosa.  Patients often have nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, sneezing, and postnasal drip that can impact quality of life.  This article focuses on allergic rhinitis, nonallergic rhinitis, and rhinitis medicamentosa.

Pathophysiology



The core mechanism underlying all forms of rhinitis involves inflammation of the nasal mucosa.  However, the specific triggers and mediators differ:

Allergic rhinitis



Development of allergic rhinitis is a 2-step process:



  • Sensitization occurs when inhaled antigens penetrate the nasal epithelium and are presented on major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules, causing activation of naive T-helper (Th) cells.  The release of cytokines (eg, IL-25, IL-33) from the nasal epithelium promotes Th2-cell differentiation, resulting in secretion of IL-4, IL-13, and other lymphokines that stimulate B-cell maturation and production of IgE antibodies.  Antigen-specific IgE antibodies then bind to the high-affinity IgE receptor on mast cells, priming the patient for an allergic response.

  • Repeated exposure to allergens (

    figure 1
    ) triggers binding of a previously recognized antigen to IgE antibodies on mast cells.  Cross-linking (
    figure 2
    ) of these antibodies leads to mast cell degranulation, which releases histamine and other inflammatory mediators.  This type I hypersensitivity reaction leads to vasodilation, increased mucus production, and tissue edema.  Repeated exposure can further increase priming, worsening symptoms over time.

Nonallergic rhinitis



Various irritants (dust, smoke, strong odors), infections (viral), hormonal fluctuations (pregnancy), and autonomic dysfunction can initiate an inflammatory response involving tachykinins, neuropeptides, and inflammatory cells.  Nonallergic rhinitis is also thought to be mediated, at least partially, by dysregulation in branches of the vagus nerve.  Subtypes include:



  • Vasomotor rhinitis:  intermittent symptoms with an exaggerated reaction to nonspecific irritants (eg, cigarette smoke, cold air)
  • Gustatory rhinitis:  triggered by hot and/or spicy foods

Rhinitis medicamentosa



Oxymetazoline, the most commonly used over-the-counter nasal decongestant spray, leads to rapid relief of nasal congestion by causing profound vasoconstriction.  However, with continued use, it can injure the vascular endothelium and induce tolerance by receptor internalization.  As alpha-adrenergic receptors become increasingly scarce and there is increased vascular permeability, the release of endogenous catecholamines is no longer sufficient to provide adequate vasoconstrictive stimulation.  This leads to rebound congestion; patients then use these alpha-adrenergic decongestants more frequently, setting up a vicious cycle that can occur in as few as 3-5 days (

figure 3
).  Intranasal cocaine use can also induce this cycle.

Risk factors

Allergic rhinitis



  • Family history of allergies
  • Atopic conditions (often considered the second step of the "atopic march," which begins with the development of eczema, then allergic rhinitis, then asthma)
  • Environmental allergen exposure (pollen, dust mites, pet dander)

Nonallergic rhinitis



  • Exposure to irritants (occupational or environmental)
  • Structural abnormalities in the nose (deviated septum, nasal polyps)
  • Hormonal fluctuations (pregnancy, hypothyroidism)
  • Certain medications (aspirin, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs)

Rhinitis medicamentosa



  • Prolonged (>3 days) use of topical nasal decongestants (oxymetazoline)

Pathology



Histopathologic examination of the nasal mucosa in rhinitis may show:



  • Edema and inflammatory cell infiltration (eosinophils in allergic rhinitis)
  • Increased mucus production
  • Goblet cell hyperplasia
  • Epithelial desquamation


The inflammatory cell infiltrate can differ in the specific types of rhinitis (eg, eosinophils in allergic rhinitis).

Clinical presentation

General manifestations



Symptoms of rhinitis can vary depending on the type and severity.  Common presentations include:



  • Sneezing:  particularly prominent in allergic rhinitis and triggered by allergen exposure
  • Rhinorrhea:  can be watery, clear, or mucopurulent depending on the cause
  • Nasal congestion:  stuffiness or blockage in the nose, causing difficulty breathing through the nose
  • Postnasal drip:  drainage of mucus down the back of the throat, leading to cough, sore throat, and voice changes
  • Itching:  primarily a symptom of allergic rhinitis, affecting the nose, eyes, and palate
  • Reduced sense of smell:  impaired ability to smell due to nasal congestion and inflammation


Specific types of rhinitis may have additional presentations:

Allergic rhinitis



Exposure to allergens results in a rapid allergic response characterized by nasal congestion, sneezing, and rhinorrhea, as well as itchy, watery eyes (allergic conjunctivitis).  Patients can often distinguish patterns in their reactions which may include the following:



  • Seasonal variation:  Exposure to specific pollen types may fluctuate at particular times of the year (eg, trees in spring, grass in summer, weeds in fall).
  • Geographic variation:  Symptoms improve when patients are not exposed to the typical allergens of the region (eg, work travel, vacation).
  • Animal exposure:  Symptoms occur when visiting a house with pets or begin shortly after animal acquisition.
  • Indoor versus outdoor:  Patients with predominantly indoor symptoms may have an allergy to dust mites; outdoor symptoms suggest pollen.


Other features sometimes seen include "allergic shiners" (infraorbital edema and darkening); the allergic salute (transverse nasal crease); enlarged, pale, bluish turbinates; pharyngeal cobblestoning; and "allergic facies" (high-arched palate, open-mouth breathing).

Nonallergic rhinitis



Symptoms can be persistent or episodic and triggered by specific irritants.  Nonallergic rhinitis does not usually cause conjunctivitis symptoms.



  • Often triggered by irritants (eg, cold air, strong smells) rather than allergens (eg, pollen)
  • Usually lacks conjunctivitis symptoms and sneezing
  • Does not usually have predictable patterns of waxing and waning

Rhinitis medicamentosa



Presentation includes persistent nasal congestion that worsens with continued use of decongestant sprays.  Patients do not often volunteer information about the use of nasal decongestant sprays.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of rhinitis is based primarily on clinical presentation and history.



  • Detailed history, including information about symptoms, duration, triggers (allergic or irritant exposure), response to medications, and medical history, is crucial.
  • Physical examination of the nose should focus on signs of inflammation, structural abnormalities (septal deviation, polyps), and nasal discharge characteristics.
  • Serum IgE levels are usually elevated in allergic rhinitis but not in nonallergic rhinitis.

Allergy testing



Antigen-specific allergy testing can be used for patients with allergic rhinitis to help guide avoidance strategies or in those considering immunotherapy.



  • Skin prick test:  A type I hypersensitivity reaction is induced.

    • Allergens are introduced into the dermis.
    • If sensitization has already occurred (which means that antigen-specific IgE is bound to the surface of mast cells), the allergen causes cross-linking of the bound IgE.
    • This cross-linking leads to degranulation of preformed histamine and leukotrienes that cause vasodilation and increased capillary permeability.  The result is a rapid (minutes) early-phase type I hypersensitivity response characterized by superficial dermal edema and erythema (eg, wheal and flare reaction).
    • There is a risk that the induced response can progress to anaphylaxis in sensitive individuals.  The treatment for anaphylaxis is epinephrine, which is less effective in patients taking beta blockers.  Therefore, the use of beta blockers is relatively contraindicated during skin prick testing.
    • Widespread skin conditions (eg, dermatitis, eczema) can also be a contraindication to skin prick testing.
  • Serum radioallergosorbent test (RAST)
    • A patient's serum is added to allergens; if the patient has preformed antibodies, they will bind to the allergen.
    • Radiolabeled antibodies that detect IgE are then added to detect those allergen-specific antibodies.
    • Patients may experience less discomfort with RAST than with skin prick testing.  RAST can be used in patients with dermatologic conditions or in those at increased risk for anaphylaxis.  However, it is less sensitive and is much more expensive than skin prick testing.

Differential diagnosis



Several conditions can mimic and/or coexist with rhinitis, including:



  • Sinusitis:  Rhinitis symptoms are accompanied by facial and/or tooth pain, pressure, and fever.
  • Nasal polyps:  Soft, noncancerous growths in the nasal passages can cause nasal obstruction and postnasal drip.  These are also from an allergic etiology.
  • Septal deviation:  A deviated septum can cause nasal obstruction and recurrent sinusitis.
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:  This rare cancer in the upper part of the throat can present with nasal congestion and discharge.
  • Drug-induced rhinitis:  Certain medications (eg, beta blockers, phosphodiesterase-5 enzyme inhibitors, alcohol) can cause nasal congestion as an adverse effect.
  • Rhinitis of pregnancy:  Approximately one-third of pregnant patients develop rhinitis in the last trimester of pregnancy; it can interfere with sleep and has an unclear pathophysiology.  This condition resolves after delivery. 

Management



Management of rhinitis focuses on controlling symptoms and improving quality of life.  The approach depends on the type and severity of rhinitis.

Allergic rhinitis



  • Allergen avoidance:  Identifying and avoiding triggers such as pollen, dust mites, or pet dander is the first line of defense.
  • Intranasal corticosteroids:  These sprays (eg,  fluticasone, budesonide) are the mainstay of treatment.  Glucocorticoids (
    figure 4
    ) bind to cytoplasmic receptors and translocate to the nucleus, where they inhibit transcription of genes that encode inflammatory mediators and decrease immune cell survival propagation.  This suppresses the immunostimulatory activity of all leukocyte cell lines, including:
    • Decreased tissue production of proinflammatory prostaglandins and leukotrienes through the inhibition of phospholipase A2
    • Decreased synthesis of proinflammatory cytokines
    • Increased synthesis of anti-inflammatory cytokines (eg, IL-10)
    • Impaired macrophage activation and neutrophil emigration
    • Increased apoptosis of eosinophils, T cells, and monocytes, perhaps by decreasing Bcl-2 expression
    • Decreased uptake of allergen particles, decreased mucus production, decreased vascular permeability
  • Antihistamines:
    • First-generation antihistamines (eg, diphenhydramine) are nonspecific and act as antagonists to multiple receptors, including the muscarinic acetylcholine receptor.  Although effective at controlling allergic rhinitis symptoms, they often have intolerable adverse anticholinergic effects (eg, urinary retention, altered mental status, decreased sweating).  They also cross the blood-brain barrier and cause sedation.
    • Second-generation antihistamines (eg, loratadine) are more specific to the histamine H1 receptor and have less permeability through the blood-brain barrier.  Although they are often less effective than first-generation antihistamines, they have significantly fewer adverse effects.
    • Intranasal antihistamines are often used with intranasal glucocorticoids with synergistic effects.
  • Leukotriene receptor antagonists:  Mast cells and eosinophils release cysteinyl-containing leukotrienes (leukotriene C4, D4, and E4) that trigger mucus secretion and edema.  Cysteinyl leukotriene receptor antagonists (eg, montelukast, zafirlukast) block these leukotriene-mediated effects to improve symptoms of allergic rhinitis.
  • Allergy immunotherapy (allergy shots or sublingual drops):  This approach involves gradual desensitization to allergens through injections, offering long-term relief for some patients.
  • Anti-IgE antibodies (eg, omalizumab):  Binding of circulating IgE decreases serum IgE levels and limits the allergen-induced immunologic response.

Nonallergic rhinitis



  • Avoidance of triggers such as dust, smoke, or strong odors is crucial.
  • Intranasal corticosteroids may be helpful for some types of nonallergic rhinitis, particularly those with a strong inflammatory component.
  • Intranasal antihistamines (eg, azelastine, olopatadine) are sometimes added to intranasal glucocorticoids for moderate to severe symptoms.
  • Nasal saline solution irrigation can help clear mucus and soothe irritated tissues.

Rhinitis medicamentosa



  • Discontinuation of the offending decongestant spray is the primary treatment.
  • Intranasal corticosteroids and/or oral glucocorticoids can help control inflammation and reduce the urge to use decongestant sprays.
  • Significant counseling is often required.

Complications and prognosis



Although not life-threatening, rhinitis can significantly impact quality of life.  Potential complications include:



  • Sleep disturbances:  Nasal congestion and postnasal drip can disrupt sleep patterns and can sometimes cause or worsen obstructive sleep apnea.
  • Sinusitis:  Chronic allergic rhinitis can increase the risk for chronic sinusitis.
  • Otitis media:  Inflammation of the middle ear (otitis media) can occur due to eustachian tube dysfunction associated with rhinitis.
  • Decreased productivity:  Symptoms can affect concentration and work performance.

Summary



Rhinitis encompasses a spectrum of inflammatory disorders affecting the nasal mucosa.  The most common types are allergic rhinitis, an IgE-mediated type I hypersensitivity reaction that occurs following repeat exposure to antigens; nonallergic rhinitis, which is a response to nonspecific irritants; and rhinitis medicamentosa, which occurs due to a cycle of increasing damage to vascular endothelial cells caused by profound vasoconstriction.  Diagnosis is usually clinical.  Management most commonly involves a combination of avoidance of triggers, intranasal glucocorticoids, and/or antihistamines.
